not sure about the tags, but `pip install superset` does not install the latest code.

We already have some component for this. I'd rather be consistent and always our component, or always use `react-copy-to-clipboard` . Not 2 different ways to do the same thing...

https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/assets/javascripts/components/CopyToClipboard.jsx

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13536974/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13536974)

Thanks for the fix! Mergin'

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13539310/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13539310)

Coverage increased (+0.8%) to 70.989% when pulling **b189984dd5bcf7fa42027e8958007e44537fa3ac on Mogball:mogball/feature/task_manager** into **064363df78da2a490a297b91fb07dd5c095548b7 on apache:master**.

Something is deleting the branch/tag (I'm suspecting some apache hook). Could have to do the fact that `0.20.0` wasn't on the master branch somehow. I just created `0.20.1` which I will merge and tag once it's in master.

Did you follow the instructions here?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#setting-up-the-node--npm-javascript-environment

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13539689/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13539689)

Coverage remained the same at 70.145% when pulling **265ca38dcdc8948367b161eb4dd3ed6c4d112b9a on mistercrunch:v0.20.1** into **064363df78da2a490a297b91fb07dd5c095548b7 on apache:master**.
@frankhsu  There's been issues where tags get deleted somehow, trying to figure this out...
I don't feel strongly about it personally
Not sure if I want Superset to become another data-pipeline scheduler... Have you checked out Apache Airflow? :)
Nice
Our heatmap is pretty much this without the digits on top, though we have a tooltip that shows the values
It's not possible at the moment. Iframe is the only way. We may release React component in the future that would assume being able to talk to an existing Superset backend.

you may have to re-write that in the dialect and use SHOW COLUMNS instead:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/athena/latest/ug/ddl/show-columns.html
@kkalyan you probably have superset already installed and need --upgrade, it installed fine here
Thanks. Sorry, but have been working only with the pypi package and wasn't aware there was a more intricate npm build. Closing.
As of now, I finally see the new releases/tags.
Still an issue, and with the limitation of running multiple queries (creating temp tables and then selecting from them) being an issue, read: it doesn't work - this is an issue.

I could setup superset env (debug mode) on Windows 8.1

The following articles were especially useful for the errors I faced.
- https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/1516#issuecomment-258319596
- https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/1235

## Environment:

- Windows 8.1 Pro
- Python 3.6.2
- Behind proxy with authentication
- cygwin (partially I use MS-DOS prompt for fabmanager)

I could avoid this error on windos env by using debug mode options.

`superset runserver -d`

While you are on it any chance you can add a comment on the correct procedure on #3511?

Hi mistercrunch,
Thanks for you comment.
I am looking something exactly as correlation matrix, where i have set of metrics on X-axis and then same set of metrics on Y-axis and then right correlation value in intersection matrix square.
Based on this , this sounds exactly of my need-  https://bl.ocks.org/arpitnarechania/caeba2e6579900ea12cb2a4eb157ce74.

With Heatmap i couldn't get option to interpolate same set of fields on x & y axis. It just allowed to choose on of field from my database table on x & another/same on y axis and then one metrics.
It would be great if you can help on this. Appreciated your input.
Thanks,
Lalan

@mistercrunch There were already checkboxes for `SQL Time Filters` and `Druid Time Filters`, nevertheless, I split them up to have one checkbox for each: `granularity_sqla`, `time_column`, `granularity`, and `druid_time_origin`, all `false` by default.

The proper way is for the owner to push to pypi. I'd rather not point directly to a repo, especially if it has no docs and stars...

We could instead remove the vids from the docs too ,they're old at this point, we need new vids

Didn't know it. Thanks for the link. A bit on overkill for my need to stage "async queries" for dashboards. I understand that this staging may be better addressed by a separate tool. So let's leave it at that.
What about the possibility to refresh slices in the background, to have the fastest response time for interactive users ?
The use case I see would be to optionally add a cron expression to tables, to define a schedule at which tables are either changed or should trigger a refresh of caches. A worker would then simply transverse all the slices dependent on table, invoking them with force=True to refresh cache.

To some extent we could see this as extending the concept of async queries beyond SQL Lab.

Scheduling cache warmup seems reasonable, and this recent PR seems like it does most of the work in that direction:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3575

Though typically in case of batch-populated tables you'd want to trigger the cache warmup after the batch job is done. That's we have a SupersetCacheWarmupOperator in Airflow at Airbnb. After the pipeline has loaded the table, we can warmup the Superset cache.

I see the use case for scheduling data transfers, but that makes Superset becomes much more of a piece of infrastructure that needs to be monitored, capped and that can be abused in intricate ways. Being on-call for Superset I'd rather people use a tool designed for that purpose. I'd be ok with it if it can be turned on and off globally. Also you'd have to have ways to limit the size of the data/query to keep the workers healthy.
I'm guessing you have unicode characters in your query?

Given the `try` statement, and the fact that removing the constraint may fail on some DB, you may want to remove the original creation of the constraint in the previous migration...
`>=3.1.25` is a bad idea as the interface is different for >=4. For Superset we generally want to pin as Superset is a product not a library. It makes sense to pin in that context.

Coverage remained the same at 70.145% when pulling **fabf61974f3032e9aa52ab78587c5083cb4313f7 on naoyak:immutablejs-mit** into **7e64f2e98868193e83536159c76226263479f91d on apache:master**.

tldr; adding `sm.get_session.close()` to the bottom of `superset/__init__.py` fixes it.

I have also experienced this bug. I think it happens because:

* `superset/__init__.py` calls
* `ConnectorRegistry.register_sources(module_datasource_map)` and that in turn does
* `__import__(module_name, fromlist=class_names)` and that ends up calling
* `flask_appbuilder.base.add_view()` which eventually calls
* `sm.add_permissions_menu()` which calls
* `find_permission_view_menu()` which does
* `return self.get_session.query(self.permissionview_model).filter_by(permission=permission, view_menu=view_menu).first()`

The final call is executing a query against the database, and because of the Python dbapi transaction semantics we now have an open, idle transaction which blocks the `CREATE TABLE`. That happens because the table has a foreign key to `ab_user` and so creating the constraint on the database requires `AccessExclusiveLock` on `ab_user`, and the transaction can't get that if there is another open transaction somewhere that has selected it somehow.

It's not clear what the best place to fix it is.
* you could file a bug against Flask-Appbuilder and propose that `add_view` should always leave the database without an open transaction - i.e. you call `self.sm.get_session.close()` at the bottom of `add_view` before `return baseview`
* you could try and fix it in `appbuilder.security.manager` by closing the session before returning the found permission/view - but that will be invasive and you would need to apply it to all the `find_` methods and it might break other things if we are calling `find` midway through a transaction to create a new menu or whatever
* you could fix it in `superset/__init__.py` by calling `sm.get_session.close` at the bottom of the file - that seems safe as we can be sure we shouldn't have any transactions in flight at that point
* you might also be able to make it work by getting the migration command to use the same session as the security manager

0.18.5 is not the latest release
looking at it

Here: superset 0.20.1

To my understanding, this issue is not related to any specific release, though.
It is more of a fundamental question whether any string can be appended or prepended to the d3 number format string.

Like in the above example, if we assume that the column we consider already is a percentage, we do not want to multiply it by 100, which happens if we specify. e.g., '.2%'. Instead, it makes sense to format the number as is and append a '%' character.

I can imagine that any sort of string concatenation would also be useful for, e.g., currencies we might want to prepend.
Correct, this is what we're looking to do rumbin.

Taking code as input is a security issue. We'd like more general support for mathematical expressions using something like `math.js`, but any use of `eval` has potential XSS vulnerabilities. I asked folks in our security team and they said that if we used `math.js` we should do it within sandboxed iframes, which I'd rather not do at this time.
